oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Confederate Monument in Columbia

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cemeteries; Soldiers; Monuments
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Columbia (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate Monument in Rose Hill Cemetery. The monument consists of a large stone pedestal with a soldier at parade rest standing on top. It is surrounded by gravestones.; Two more unidentified monuments can be seen behind it. The engraved text states the monument is dedicated to "heroes of 1861-1865."

A face-off at Columbia led to a brief Southern victory in the Franklin-Nashville struggle in late November 1864. Confederate Gen. Hood set up a diversion to cut off the Federal army's line of communications with Nashville.; Federal Gen. Schofield correctly interpreted Hood's moves, but bad weather kept him from crossing to the north bank, leaving Columbia to the Confederates. Thus Schofield slowed Hood's movement but could not stop him.
